the gold standard right now is to use a
sound booth to attenuate ambient noise
and then use an audio meter with
different mechanisms to in test to test
for hearing that can be pure tone
threshold test where you raise your hand
when you hear the tone to figure out
what the threshold is you can also do
bone conduction where that vibration in
your bone actually travels to your inner
ear and you hear it as a sound that
bypasses the outer ear in the middle ear
so it helps you understand where the
issue really is if there is one and then
finally there's a mechanism where you
can actually play two tones for example
they're fairly close together into your
ear and then there's a little microphone
and that dynamic response of your inner
ear actually emits Auto acoustic
emission emits a frequency that is some
multiple the difference of those two
frequencies and so that's actually
reveals some of something about the
health of the inner ear that you don't
get from the other tests and so often
times up for example if we're dealing
with mouse models right Mouse can't
raise your hand I've heard the tone or
not so you need other ways to to
